questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given.

 

Reason: The combination covers gram positive organisms as well as anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A is true and R is false

 

  • In patients admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given. Beta lactams covers the gram positive and gram negative organisms whereas azithromycin covers the atypical mycobacteria like mycoplasma and chlamydia.
  • Alternative to this therapy is fluoroquinolones.
  • If a patient is not admitted, then either beta lactams alone or macrolides is prescribed.

 

Educational objective:

 

In hospitalized patients with community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is used to cover typical and atypical bacterial pathogens, not anaerobes.

 

Reference: Katzung 13th/878

questions.text: According to the current biomedical waste management guidelines, which colored bin should be used for the disposal of blood bag? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow bin 

 

  • Yellow Bin: Used for human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, and clinical lab waste.
  • This includes items such as body parts, blood bags, and items contaminated with body fluids.
  • The disposal methods typically involve incineration, plasma pyrolysis, deep burial, or chemical treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

 

Genomic Imprinting is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents.

 

Important functional differences exist between the paternal allele and the maternal allele. These differences result from an epigenetic process, called imprinting. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

 

Genomic imprinting is a process of silencing genes through DNA methylation. The repressed allele is methylated, while the active allele is unmethylated.

 

E.g., Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Both of these syndromes can be caused by imprinting or other errors involving genes on the long arm of chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal mosaicism: Gonadal mosaicism refers to the presence of more than one genetically distinct cell line within the gonads. This can lead to different genetic outcomes in offspring but does not involve the differential effect of the same gene based on parental origin. Therefore, it is not related to genomic imprinting.

 

Option C. Anticipation: Anticipation is a phenomenon where a genetic disorder appears earlier and with increased severity in successive generations. This is different from genomic imprinting, as it does not involve the differential effects of a gene based on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father.

 

Option D. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance occurs when not all individuals carrying a disease-causing mutation exhibit the disease phenotype. This concept is unrelated to the differential effect of a gene based on its parental origin and does not describe genomic imprinting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 328

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Striate cortex

 

Explanation:

 

  • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.
  • The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience.
  • The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cortex: The orbital cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing and decision-making. It is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is a crucial structure for memory formation and spatial navigation. While it has connections to other parts of the brain, its primary connection to the corpus callosum is through the more anterior parts, not the splenium.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It is a structure located at the base of the brain where some of the optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain. This crossover allows for the integration of visual input from both eyes, but it occurs before the information reaches the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The corpus callosum is divided into four parts: 
    • The rostrum is continuous with the lamina terminalis and connects the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The genu is the bend of the anterior corpus callosum and the forceps minor is a tract that projects fibres from the genu to connect the medial and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The body forms the long central section and its fibres pass through the corona radiata to reach the surface of the hemispheres. 
    • The splenium tapers away at the posterior section, with the forceps major projecting fibres from the splenium to connect the two occipital lobes. Striate cortex (visual area) is located in occupital lobe.
  • The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

 

Resistance to ganciclovir (GCV) most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene.

 

Viral UL97 kinase and UL54 DNA polymerase gene mutations are well-documented mechanisms of resistance to current antivirals. The UL97 kinase normally phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of various cellular and viral proteins, and is required for efficient CMV replication. This kinase also effects the initial phosphorylation of GCV that is required for antiviral activity, and UL97 mutations that impair this phosphorylation are the preferred mechanism of GCV resistance.

 

UL54 mutations can confer resistance to all current drugs and may emerge after prolonged GCV therapy to increase the level of resistance conferred by a pre-existing UL97 mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

 

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical. In immunocompromised individuals, CMV can cause various manifestations, including retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis, but watery diarrhea is not the most common manifestation.

 

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscamet. These mutations affect the viral DNA polymerase, leading to cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date canâ€™t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text:
A team of researchers is conducting investigations to evaluate the impact of interventions targeting a specific disease. Two independent studies, labeled as A and B, are analyzed. Study A utilized an intervention denoted as "X", and Study B utilized an intervention denoted as "Y". Both studies incorporate control groups. The calculated p-values for studies A and B, with 95% confidence intervals, were found to be 0.02 and 0.001, respectively.  Based on this information, which of the following conclusions is most appropriate? [AIIMS MAY 2019]

 

  1. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X.
  2. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to Intervention Y.
  3. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A.
  4. Both study A and B show a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) If 1 and 3 are correct

 

  • Statements 1 and 3 are accurate. The p-value for study A involving intervention X within a 95% confidence interval stands at 0.02.
  • In the case of study B, employing intervention Y within the same confidence interval, the p-value is 0.001.
  • Both studies' probability (p) values fall below the 0.05 threshold (level of significance - Î±), leading to the conclusion that both studies A and B hold significance and thus warrant the rejection of the null hypothesis.
  • Nevertheless, study B exhibits a p-value lower than that of study A, implying that the precision and significance of study B, involving intervention Y, surpass those of study A with intervention X.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 2: This is incorrect as it mistakenly asserts that Study A, which had a higher p-value, would be more precise and that intervention X would be more significant than intervention Y. This is opposite to what the p-values suggest.

 

Option 4: Also incorrect because it suggests that both interventions have similar statistical significance, which contradicts the considerable difference in their p-values. A lower p-value in Study B indicates a stronger statistical significance compared to Study A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In interpreting clinical study results, a lower p-value indicates stronger evidence against the null hypothesis and typically points to a more significant intervention effect.
  • In this scenario, Study B's intervention (Y) is statistically more significant than Study A's intervention (X), indicating a potentially more effective or impactful intervention.

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches â€“ originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

choices.text: Vicarious liability
Doctrine of negligent choice
Contributory negligence
Borrowed servant doctrine

questions.text: A surgeon lends his assistant to a physician; the new employer is responsible for his actions by? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Borrowed servant doctrine  

 

The borrowed servant rule is a legal doctrine in which an employer is held liable for the actions of a temporary employee. When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily surrenders control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Vicarious liability: Incorrect. Vicarious liability is a legal principle where an employer is held responsible for the actions of their employees while they are performing their job duties. However, it does not specifically address situations involving borrowed employees.

 

Option B. Doctrine of negligent choice: Incorrect. The doctrine of negligent choice involves holding someone liable for choosing an incompetent or unfit person to perform a task. This doctrine is not directly relevant to the situation described.

 

Option C. Contributory negligence: Incorrect. Contributory negligence refers to a situation where the injured party has, through their own negligence, contributed to the harm they suffered. It does not apply to the responsibility of an employer for the actions of a borrowed employee.

 

Educational objective

 

The borrowed servant doctrine holds that the borrowing employer assumes liability for the actions of an employee borrowed from another employer during the period of borrowing. This ensures that the temporary employer is responsible for supervising and controlling the borrowed employee.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reasons are correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The assertion is correct statement, but the Reasons is incorrect statement.
The assertion is independently an incorrect statement, but the Reasons is a correct statement.

questions.text:
Assertion: The most common hematological finding in a case of lead poisoning is eosinophilia.


Reason: Lead causes inhibition of ALA Dehydratase.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The assertion is independently an incorrect statement, but the Reasons is a correct statement.

 

The assertion that "the most common hematological finding in lead poisoning is eosinophilia" is incorrect. The typical hematological findings in lead poisoning include anemia, basophilic stippling of red blood cells, and the presence of ringed sideroblasts. Eosinophilia is not a characteristic finding in cases of lead toxicity.

 

The reason provided, "Lead causes inhibition of ALA Dehydratase," is true. Lead toxicity interferes with heme synthesis by inhibiting enzymes such as ALA Dehydratase and Ferrochelatase. This inhibition contributes to the accumulation of intermediates and results in anemia with basophilic stippling of RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lead poisoning, typical hematological findings include anemia and basophilic stippling, not eosinophilia. Lead toxicity inhibits enzymes critical for heme synthesis, such as ALA Dehydratase.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A patient with HIV develops diarrhea and faecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with cotrimoxazole. Diarrhoea subsided but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image below. Which of the following statement is false? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

Based on the clinical picture, an HIV positive patient had infection with Isospora belli which was treated with cotrimoxazole. The bone marrow examination showed narrow based budding yeast cells suggestive of infection with Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus which exists as a mycelial form at ambient temperatures and grows as small round budding yeast cells at body temperature in mammals.
  • Growth on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25ÂºC shows a white to brown colony, cottony mycelium after 2 to 3 weeks.
  • The mold phase is characterized by thin, branching, septate hyphae that produce microconidia and a very distinct spore called a tuberculate macroconidium.
  • Grown at 37ÂºC shows the budding yeast form. Yeast cells occur within budding yeasts as intracellular fungi.
  • The yeast cell is 2-4 Âµm in diameter and slightly oval in shape and found exclusively within macrophages.
  • Mode of infection - Inhalation of spores
  • Disseminated infection can occur in immunocompromised patients with reticuloendothelial system being affected the most.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: Correct. Spores of Histoplasma capsulatum are the infective form. They are inhaled into the lungs, where they convert to yeast form and cause infection.

 

Option C. It is intracellular budding yeast: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular budding yeast when it infects the host. It is typically found within macrophages.

 

Option D. It can cause systemic disease: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause systemic disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, a thermally dimorphic fungus, can grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar, produce infective spores, exist as an intracellular budding yeast in humans, and cause systemic disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On USG, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid renal mass that may enhance heterogeneously after contrast administration and generally does not contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: A benign renal tumor that typically appears as a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing mass on imaging, without the characteristic fat component seen in angiomyolipomas.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled, round structure with no enhancement; the lesion in the image is solid with fatty components, inconsistent with a simple cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant Disorders

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by a consistent appearance of affected individuals in every generation, with no sex bias and manifestation in individuals who carry one copy of the mutant allele.

questions.text: What is the definitive approach for managing uncontrollable vertigo caused by Meniere's disease?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labyrinthectomy

 

Definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniereâ€™s disease is labyrinthectomy.

 

The step-up management of Meniereâ€™s disease is

 

  1. Dietary changes â€“ low salt and caffeine free diet
  2. First-line medical treatment to prevent recurrence of vertigo may include betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg thrice daily and/or diuretics. Betahistine has a limited side effect profile while diuretics can cause electrolyte disturbances, potentially interacting with patient-specific drugs and conditions.
  3. Salvage treatment in case of medical treatment failure may include repetitive intratympanic injections of dexamethasone.
  4. In refractory cases after intratympanic injection of dexamethasone, intratympanic injection of gentamicin (as-needed) can be offered (recommendation grade A). This treatment is based on the vestibulotoxic effect of gentamicin and aims to destroy vestibular hair cell function (therefore also called partial chemo labyrinthectomy).
  5. Surgical destruction (Labyrinthectomy, Vestibular nerve section): Labyrinthectomy totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function and are thus used only when cochlear function is not serviceable and when conservative treatments fail. It has shown the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), and is considered as the single definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide: This medication is not typically used as a definitive treatment for Meniere's disease. It may be used in some cases for its diuretic effect to manage symptoms, but it does not address the root causes or provide long-term control of vertigo.

 

Option C. Vestibular neurectomy: This surgical procedure involves severing the vestibular nerve to alleviate vertigo while preserving hearing. It is considered for patients where hearing preservation is a priority, but it is not as definitive as labyrinthectomy for completely eliminating vertigo.

 

Option D. Intratympanic gentamicin: This treatment involves injecting gentamicin, a vestibulotoxic antibiotic, into the middle ear to chemically ablate vestibular function. It is used as a salvage treatment for vertigo control in Meniere's disease when other medical treatments fail. However, it is not considered as definitive as labyrinthectomy due to its potential for hearing loss and the need for repeated treatments in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Meniere's disease who have debilitating vertigo and no serviceable hearing in the affected ear, labyrinthectomy offers a definitive solution with a very high success rate in eliminating vertigo. This surgical option is reserved for severe cases where other less invasive treatments have been exhausted.

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination, he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Opening pressure- increased
  • Proteins- mildly increased
  • Glucose â€“ normal
  • Lymphocytes- increased
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coxsackie

 

The CSF findings indicative of increased lymphocytes, normal glucose levels, and mildly increased protein are characteristic of viral meningitis. Coxsackie virus, a common cause of viral meningitis, often presents with these CSF findings. The typical profile of viral meningitis includes normal glucose levels, which helps differentiate it from bacterial, fungal, and tuberculous meningitis where glucose levels are often decreased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Tuberculous meningitis typically shows low glucose, high protein, and a mixed cellular response in the CSF, which does not match the patient's CSF profile.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhea: Generally causes bacterial meningitis with a different CSF profileâ€”low glucose, high protein, and predominantly polymorphonuclear cells.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Fungal meningitis also shows low glucose and is not consistent with the normal glucose levels observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an â€œonion skinâ€ periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of â€œCodmanâ€™s triangleâ€, or it may have a â€œsunburstâ€ or â€œhair on endâ€ appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codmanâ€™s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text:
Choose the true statements:

 

  1. The most commonly fractured carpal bone is the lunate
  2. The scaphoid is most commonly fractured at the waist
  3. The cast for scaphoid fracture is set in a glass-holding position
  4. Kienböck's disease is due to osteonecrosis of the lunate
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii, iii, and iv only

 

  • Statement ii: True. The scaphoid is most commonly fractured at the waist. Scaphoid fractures are more common in young adults and frequently occur at the waist of the scaphoid.
  • Statement iii: True. The cast for scaphoid fractures is set in a glass-holding position. This involves immobilizing the affected hand in a cast extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, including the thumb, in a slight dorsiflexion and radial deviation.
  • Statement iv: True. Kienböck's disease is due to osteonecrosis of the lunate bone. It often presents with pain and stiffness in the wrist, typically in young adults.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement i: False. The most commonly fractured carpal bone is the scaphoid, not the lunate. The scaphoid is more prone to fractures due to its position and structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone, typically at its waist, and its fractures are immobilized using a cast in a glass-holding position. Kienböck's disease involves osteonecrosis of the lunate.

choices.text: It occurs as a sequela following infection with Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Seizures, personality changes, and myoclonus are common clinical features
EEG shows a characteristic periodic sharp wave pattern
Symptoms typically present 8 - 10 years after the initial infection

questions.text: Identify the statement that is false regarding Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis (SSPE).
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs as a sequela following infection with Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)

 

It occurs as a sequela following infection with Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) - False
This statement is false. Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal complication that occurs as a delayed consequence of measles (Rubeola) virus infection, not Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV). SSPE typically manifests years after the initial measles infection, often in childhood or adolescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Seizures, personality changes, and myoclonus are common clinical features â€“ True: SSPE often presents with symptoms including personality changes, intellectual decline, seizures, and myoclonus (involuntary muscle jerks). These progressive neurological symptoms are characteristic of SSPE.

 

Option C. EEG shows a characteristic periodic sharp wave pattern â€“ True:  The EEG in SSPE is distinctive, often showing a periodic pattern with bursts of high-voltage, sharp waves or slow waves occurring every 3-8 seconds. This pattern is a hallmark of SSPE.

 

Option D. Symptoms typically present 8 - 10 years after the initial infection â€“ True:  SSPE generally appears as a late complication, emerging about 5-15 years after the initial measles infection, with an average onset around 8-10 years. This delayed onset is typical of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSPE is a late-onset, progressive, and fatal neurological disorder resulting from a previous measles infection, not VZV. It commonly presents years after the initial infection with specific clinical and EEG findings.

choices.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain
Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

 

  • Identify visible larger mercury beads and push together using Cardboards and collect using Syringe without needle.
  • Store collected mercury beads in an air tight plastic bag and label it properly. Put all the items that were used to pick up the mercury, including index cards or cardboard, eyedropper, contaminated tape, paper towels, and zipper-type bags into the trash bag. Carefully seal the trash bag that contains the mercury contaminated waste and dispose them properly.
  • Do not use a vacuum, broom or paint brush to clean up the spill. These methods can spread the mercury to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

choices.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy
ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy
ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy

questions.text: Identify this condition? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic placenta, characterized by a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both a chorion and an amniotic sac. This type of twinning occurs when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation, after the formation of the trophoblast, leading to a monochorionic condition.

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestations have a high fetal death rate due to several complications:

 

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

 

The best time for delivery of monochorionic monoamniotic twins is between 32-34 weeks via Caesarean section.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome: This is a complication seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies. It involves a donor twin and a recipient twin. The donor twin is anemic, growth-restricted, and has oligohydramnios, while the recipient twin is polycythemic, has polyhydramnios, and suffers from circulatory overload.

 

Option B. Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In this type of pregnancy, there are two amniotic cavities and one chorion. This occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 4-7 days of gestation.

 

Option D. Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy: This pregnancy type involves two amniotic cavities and two chorions. It occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 0-3 days of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies involve a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane, occurring when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 233-234,

choices.text: Necrotizing TB granuloma
Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
Severe fungal pneumonia

questions.text: A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, with desaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvement of right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. On autopsy, the lungs, appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia

 

The above image shows a foreign body granuloma. Foreign bodies are surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes. This change results from aspiration of stomach contents or food particles in this case probably vegetative matter.

 

Aspiration pneumonia occurs in markedly debilitated patients or those who aspirate gastric contents either while unconscious (e.g., after a stroke) or during repeated vomiting. These patients have abnormal gag and swallowing reflexes that predispose to aspiration. The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical because of the extremely irritating effects of the gastric acid, and partly bacterial (from the oral flora). Typically, more than one organism is recovered on culture, aerobes being more common than anaerobes. This type of pneumonia is often necrotizing, pursues a fulminant clinical course, and is a frequent cause of death.

 

The most commonly affected lobes in Necrotizing pneumonia are the right middle and lower lobes, consistent with the findings in this case.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing TB granuloma: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not foreign body granulomas as seen in this image. The clinical scenario also does not support TB.

 

Option C. Sarcoid granuloma: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, which differ from the foreign body granuloma seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Severe fungal pneumonia: Fungal infections can cause granulomatous inflammation, but they typically present with necrotizing granulomas or other distinct histological features. The presence of foreign material is more indicative of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia can lead to the formation of foreign body granulomas, characterized by macrophages and lymphocytes surrounding the aspirated material. This condition is often associated with severe clinical outcomes, especially in debilitated patients.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No 1344

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the nutritional targets of Mid-Day Meal Program, as per the Indian government guidelines? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1/2 protein and 1/3 calorie requirements

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as â€˜School Lunch Programmeâ€™, it has been in operation since 1961.
    • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
    • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
    • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
    • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
    • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal -

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.text: To accurately calculate the perinatal mortality rate, which of the following should specifically be considered as part of the numerator? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g 

 

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR)

 

  • It includes both late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.

 

 

  • Perinatal period is from 28 weeks period of gestation to 7th completed days of life (But the WHO definition of perinatal period is from 22 completed weeks gestation to 7th completed days of life).
  • PNMR is a major marker to assess the quality of health care delivery; PNMR is aâ€ Yardstick of Obstetric and Pediatric care before and around the time of birthâ€
  • P List (ICD 10): 100 causes of perinatal mortality and morbidity
  • PNMR of India (2022) - 18 per 1000 LB (SRS, September 2022)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths, focusing on the period from 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner plexiform layer

 

The inner plexiform layer is marked in the above histological image of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner plexiform layer of the retina is a crucial site for synaptic activity among various retinal cells, playing a key role in the preprocessing of visual information before it is sent to the brain. Recognizing this layer and understanding its function are important for comprehending the overall neural circuitry of the retina.

choices.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer
Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity
Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the  diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

 

This is the correct match. Fluorescein, when used with a cobalt blue light, stains areas of corneal epithelial loss, highlighting defects such as corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer: Trypan blue is generally used in cataract surgery to stain the anterior capsule, not for diagnosing corneal ulcers.

 

Option B. Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity: Rose Bengal stain is actually used to detect damage to the eye's surface cells, particularly in cases of dry eye where these cells are more vulnerable. 

 

Option D. Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion: Lissamine green stains areas of cell loss or damage on the surface of the eye, such as in cases of corneal abrasion or dry eye. Itâ€™s used under white light rather than cobalt blue light.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorescein stain under cobalt blue light remains a standard and effective method for diagnosing corneal ulcers due to its ability to vividly highlight areas of epithelial loss.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

 

An increase in heart rate is the best sign that a ventilatory effort is working.

 

When newborns are unable to breathe on their own, positive pressure ventilation, or PP, is used. To ensure that the airway is open, the infant's neck is slightly stretched in this position. An appropriate-sized face mask is chosen so that it may cover the mouth and nose when the care provider is at the baby's head end. For a good seal, it should be gripped firmly, and compression is applied using the fingers.

 

Visible chest rise is a sign of adequate ventilation, and ventilation should be initiated when normal chest rise is seen.

 

The baby's progress is measured by an increase in heart rate, spontaneous breathing, and improvement in colour.

 

When there is no rise in heart rate, ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows

 

  • Mask has to be reapplied
  • The infant's head is repositioned
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated. Also, the pressure is increased slightly.
  • Change the airway

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is a component of APGAR score

 

Option C. Air entry: Air entry is checked during intubation to check weather the endotracheal tube is in centre which gives equal air entry to both lungs.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Chest rise is also seen once we do bag and mask ventilation but the most important indicator is rising heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

questions.text: A female patient presented with swollen and tender joints. There is symmetric involvement of multiple joints such as wrists, hands, and feet, which is bilateral, along with morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour. Erythema is absent. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rheumatoid arthritis


In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with swollen and tender joints, and the symmetric involvement of joints, such as the wrists, hands, and feet, is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The presence of morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour is also a key feature of RA. RA is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the synovium of joints, leading to pain, swelling, and stiffness, particularly in the small joints of the hands and feet.

 

Signs and symptoms of RA include:

 

  • Symmetric joint pain and swelling, especially in the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • Morning stiffness that lasts more than 1 hour.
  • Deformities such as Swan-neck and Boutonnière deformities.
  • Constitutional symptoms like weight loss and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gout: Gout typically presents as acute, episodic attacks of severe joint pain, often starting in a single joint like the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joint. Gout is usually not symmetric, making it unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is characterized by degenerative joint changes and is more common in older adults. It often involves weight-bearing joints such as the knees and hips, as well as the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints in the hands. Morning stiffness in osteoarthritis typically lasts less than 30 minutes.

 

Option D. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is associated with skin changes of psoriasis and can involve the DIP joints, often in an asymmetric pattern. It may also present with "sausage-shaped" fingers (dactylitis). The absence of skin changes and the symmetric pattern makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by symmetric joint involvement, primarily affecting small joints like the MCP and PIP joints, with morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour. It presents with chronic inflammation and is differentiated from other types of arthritis by these clinical features and serological markers like rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP antibodies.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is classified as which type of synovial joint? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

 

Explanation:

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

 

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.

 

Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is  a ball and socket joint.

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain and swelling in the left side of his scrotum. The surgeon suspects testicular torsion based on the clinical presentation. Which is the most appropriate next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side

 

In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step in management for suspected testicular torsion. It involves immediate surgical exploration of both the symptomatic (painful) side and the asymptomatic (contralateral) side. Even if only one side appears to be affected, there is a risk of contralateral testicular torsion in future. This occurs as the same anatomical abnormality (high investment of tunica vaginalis/transverse testis are likely to be present on both sides.
  • The surgeon can detorse (untwist) the affected testicle and fixate it to prevent future torsion. Contralateral scrotum is explored and orchidopexy is done to prevent future risk of torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of testicular torsion: 

 

  • Timely diagnosis: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires prompt diagnosis and management to salvage the testis as the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.
  • Surgery: The definitive management of testicular torsion is surgical exploration with detorsion and fixation of the testis to prevent future torsion. The surgery should be performed within 6 hours of the onset of symptoms to maximize the chances of testicular salvage. At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed as the same anatomic defect can allow torsion on the contralateral side.

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT 


The macula densa consists of specialized cells located at the distal end of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, where it meets the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). These cells are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which helps regulate blood pressure and filtration rate within the kidneys by monitoring sodium concentration in the filtrate. The macula densa responds to changes in sodium chloride concentration by signaling the juxtaglomerular cells to either increase or decrease renin release, thus impacting the glomerular filtration rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of thick descending limb and DCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not located at the junction of the thick descending limb of the loop of Henle and the DCT. The descending limb is involved in water reabsorption, and its function differs from that of the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Junction of thick descending limb and PCT: Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is located at the start of the nephron, near the glomerulus, and does not meet the thick descending limb of the loop of Henle where the macula densa is located.

 

Option D. Junction of DCT and collecting duct: Incorrect. The distal convoluted tubule (DCT) connects to the collecting duct further downstream from the location of the macula densa. The macula densa is specifically positioned near the end of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:


The macula densa is located at the junction of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), and is an integral part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus responsible for regulating kidney function and blood pressure through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

choices.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. MRI

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus.
  • Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (â€œapical capâ€).
  • Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive.
  • MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.

 

Regional spread can cause:

 

  • Tracheal obstruction

  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia

  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness

  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea

  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: While helpful for initial evaluation, it lacks the detail required to assess soft tissue involvement and the exact extent of the tumor.

 

Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb: Useful for vascular assessment but not suitable for visualizing intrathoracic tumors or their impact on neural structures.

 

Option C. HRCT: High-resolution CT can identify the presence of an apical mass but does not provide as detailed visualization of soft tissue and neurovascular involvement as MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Pancoast tumor, MRI is preferred over other imaging modalities for its superior ability to delineate the extent of tumor involvement with the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus, critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

 

The "a" wave on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing represents atrial contraction. This wave occurs when the right atrium contracts, pushing blood into the right ventricle. It is the first positive deflection in the JVP waveform and is a key component in assessing right atrial pressure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial filling: Incorrect. Atrial filling is represented by the v wave, which occurs as the atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole.

 

Option C. Ventricular relaxation: Incorrect. Ventricular relaxation corresponds to the x descent and y descent in the JVP tracing.

 

Option D. Ventricular filling: Incorrect. Ventricular filling is associated with the y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).
