Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: ICER is used as an Economic model in which of the following Health Management Techniques: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost effectiveness analysis

 

ICER stands for Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio. It is a measure used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the differences in cost between two interventions relative to the differences in their effectiveness or results. The formula for calculating ICER is:

 

ICER = (Câ‚ - Câ‚€) / (Eâ‚ - Eâ‚€)

 

Where:

 

  • Câ‚ and Eâ‚ represent the cost and effectiveness of the intervention being evaluated
  • Câ‚€ and Eâ‚€ represent the cost and effectiveness of the control or comparison intervention

 

ICER is primarily used in cost-effectiveness analysis when comparing treatment alternatives, especially when expressed in terms of quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). It helps decision-makers determine if the additional cost of a more effective intervention is worth the additional benefit gained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost benefit analysis: This is incorrect because cost-benefit analysis expresses both costs and benefits in monetary terms, whereas ICER is used in cost-effectiveness analysis where effectiveness is measured in non-monetary outcomes (like life years gained or QALYs).

 

Option C. Systems analysis: This is incorrect because systems analysis is a problem-solving approach that involves comparing alternative cost-effective solutions in a health program. 

 

Option D. Cost accounting: This is incorrect because cost accounting deals with the basic cost structure of a health program and the allocation of resources. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) is a key economic model used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the relative costs and outcomes of different interventions.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Filariasis

 

Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

 

Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is targeted for global elimination through treatment of entire at-risk populations with repeated annual mass drug administration (MDA). Essential for program success is defining and confirming the appropriate endpoint for MDA when transmission is presumed to have reached a level low enough that it cannot be sustained even in the absence of drug intervention. Guidelines advanced by WHO call for a transmission assessment survey (TAS) to determine if MDA can be stopped within an LF evaluation unit (EU) after at least five effective rounds of annual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium vivax, which causes malaria.

 

Option B. P. falciparum: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium falciparum, another cause of malaria.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Transmission assessment surveys are not used for Leishmania species, which cause leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) are essential tools used to evaluate the success of mass drug administration programs for lymphatic filariasis and determine if the transmission levels are low enough to discontinue these programs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

This was an atypical question, which is important only if it is repeated in a subsequent exam.

 

The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) - Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) type.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.

 

The median patient age is about 60 years, but DLBCL also occurs in young adults and children.

 

DLBCL commonly presents with enlarged lymph nodes or rapidly growing mass along with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The B symptoms can be seen in 30% of the patients. Bone marrow involvement is more common in indolent disease and can be seen in up to 50% of the cases.

 

About 50% of the patients have extranodal involvement like stomach or gastrointestinal tract (most common primary extranodal site), skin, bones, spinal cord, testicles, among other locations. Renal involvement can be secondary to bulky disease or lymphadenopathy, causing a ureteral obstruction or due to tumor lysis syndrome. DLBCL can also present with symptoms suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome, compression of the airways. The symptoms can be related to the infiltrated organ if the disease spreads beyond the lymphatics in so-called extranodal disease. A variety of paraneoplastic syndromes may also be associated with B cell lymphomas.

 

Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

 

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far, only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glioblastoma multiforme: Most common sites are the frontal and temporal lobes. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination, dense dura around intracranial veins and lack of nurturing stroma in other organs.

 

 

Option B. Hodgkinâ€™s Lymphoma: Doesnâ€™t involve the extra nodal sites

 

Option D. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: These tumors primarily metastasize to the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone, in order of frequency. Although CNS involvement can occur, it is relatively rare. The combination of scrotal swelling and ataxia is less typical for non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile includes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NST and AFI

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes two key components: the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI). This abbreviated version of the BPP focuses on assessing fetal well-being through these two measures. The NST evaluates fetal heart rate patterns in response to fetal movements, while the AFI assesses the amount of amniotic fluid, which can indicate the health of the placenta and overall fetal condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NST and fetal tone: This combination is not the Modified BPP. While the NST is part of the Modified BPP, fetal tone is part of the complete Biophysical Profile but not included in the Modified BPP.

 

Option C. NST and breathing movements: Breathing movements are part of the complete Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which only uses NST and AFI.

 

Option D. NST and gross fetal movements: Gross fetal movements are part of the full Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which comprises only NST and AFI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI).

 

Ref: Page no 980, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Abruptio placentae, also known as placental abruption, commonly occurs in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. It is characterized by the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often fetal distress or fetal death. The uterus may be tonically contracted in such cases.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs.
  • Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves painless vaginal bleeding due to the placenta covering the cervix. It generally does not cause decreased fetal movements unless there is severe bleeding leading to maternal and fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid and does not typically present with bleeding.

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor typically does not present with bleeding and is characterized by regular uterine contractions leading to cervical changes before 37 weeks of gestation. Prematurity in preterm labor is iatrogenic if induced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abruptio placenta should be suspected in a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements, as it is commonly associated with hypertensive disorders and presents with these clinical features.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1944

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its Î²-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novakâ€™s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs correctly match the techniques of organ removal in autopsy?

 

  1. Letulle - one by one
  2. Virchow - en masse
  3. Ghon's - En bloc
  4. Rokitansky - in situ
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

  • Ghon's technique: In this method, organs are removed "en bloc," meaning groups of organs (e.g., thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs) are taken out as blocks. This method allows for systematic dissection of interconnected organs as single units.
  • Rokitansky's technique: Characterized by "in situ" dissection, where organs are examined and dissected within the body before partial removal. It combines some aspects of en bloc removal for thorough examination, often starting from the neck and moving downwards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Letulle - one by one: This is incorrect because Letulle's technique involves the removal of organs "en masse" or as one large organ block, not individually.

 

Option B. Virchow - en masse: Incorrect as Virchowâ€™s technique involves removing organs one by one rather than en masse, allowing for a separate and thorough examination of each organ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ghon's technique involves en bloc organ removal, and Rokitansky's technique is an in situ dissection approach in autopsy procedures.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

choices.text: Aspiration pneumonia â€“ Upper segment of right lower lobe

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic presented with fever, malaise, and cough. His chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial infiltrates â€“ Mycoplasma

 

The chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, particularly in the lower lobes. This pattern is characteristic of atypical pneumonia, specifically Mycoplasma pneumonia. In Mycoplasma infections, infiltrates tend to be interstitial and patchy, not dense consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobar infiltrates â€“ Pyogenic pneumonia: Incorrect. Pyogenic pneumonia typically shows dense consolidation with air bronchograms in a lobar distribution

 

Option B. Hilar infiltrates â€“ Malignancy: Incorrect. Hilar regions appear normal. Malignancy typically presents with hilar masses or lymphadenopathy

 

Option D. Aspiration pneumonia â€“ Upper segment of right lower lobe: Incorrect. Although aspiration pneumonia often affects this segment, this patient shows no risk factors for aspiration and has bilateral infiltrates

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, along with fever, malaise, and cough, are characteristic of atypical pneumonia, particularly Mycoplasma pneumonia.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.

questions.text: In which of the following bags are latex gloves disposed of after use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red

 

Latex gloves are disposed of in a red-colored bag after use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow: Incorrect. Yellow bags are used for human anatomical waste and soiled waste like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood or body fluids.

 

Option C. Blue: Incorrect. Blue bags are used for glassware and metal implants in biomedical waste management.

 

Option D. Transparent: Incorrect. Transparent bags are not typically used for biomedical waste; they may be used for regular waste or in other non-hazardous contexts.

 

Educational Objective:


Proper disposal of biomedical waste is crucial for infection control and environmental safety. Latex gloves, after use, should be disposed of in a red bag, which is designated for items like contaminated plastic waste.

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased sleep: Individuals might sleep more than usual.

 

Option B. Reactive mood: While the individuals typically have a depressed mood, their mood can temporarily lift in response to positive events.

 

Option C. Heaviness of the body: Often described as "leaden paralysis," especially in the arms and legs.

 

However, the claim that atypical depression responds better to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) than to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) is incorrect. In reality, atypical depression often responds better to SSRIs & MAO-Is than to TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), presence of mood reactivity, leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection. SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

choices.text: It is a dematiaceous fungus
Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or joints
Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.

choices.text: Made of amino acids and sugars

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about proteoglycans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Holds less water

 

Proteoglycans are widely distributed complex molecules having glycosaminoglycans (GAG) and proteins. The GAGs containing repeating disaccharide units are covalently bound to the peptide chain to form proteoglycans. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Chondroitin sulfate It is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid â†’ beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate â†’ beta-1, 4 and so on. It is a glycosaminoglycan bound to a protein; hence it is a proteoglycan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carries Negative Charge: Proteoglycans carry negative charges due to the presence of sulfate and carboxyl groups on the GAG chains. These negatively charged groups attract positively charged ions and water molecules.

 

Option B. Chondroitin Sulfate is a Proteoglycan: Chondroitin sulfate is a type of GAG that, when attached to a core protein, forms a proteoglycan. It is widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, and skin.

 

Option C. Made of Amino Acids and Sugars: Proteoglycans are made up of a protein core (composed of amino acids) and one or more GAG chains (composed of sugars).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteoglycans are complex molecules made of amino acids and sugars, carrying negative charges and holding a significant amount of water due to their hydrophilic nature. Chondroitin sulfate, a type of GAG, forms proteoglycans when bound to a protein.

choices.text: NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via lgE antibodies).

 

In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

 

 

Role of NK Cells: NK cells are key mediators of ADCC. They express the Fc receptor CD16 (FcγRIII), which specifically recognizes the Fc portion of IgG antibodies bound to target cells. Upon engagement, NK cells degranulate, releasing cytotoxic molecules that induce apoptosis in the target cell.

 

Role of Neutrophils and Eosinophils: Eosinophils are particularly involved in the ADCC response against larger parasites, such as helminths, where they utilize IgE antibodies to recognize and attack these pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is primarily mediated by NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which kill target cells coated with antibodies through mechanisms that do not involve phagocytosis.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 356

questions.text: Mitochondria of spermatozoa form the: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle piece


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece of the sperm. The middle piece contains numerous mitochondria arranged in a helical pattern around the axoneme. These mitochondria are essential for providing the energy required for sperm motility through ATP production.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Head sheath: Incorrect because the head contains the nucleus and acrosome, not mitochondria 

 

Option B. Connecting part: Incorrect as it's just a transitional region 

 

Option D. Tail: Incorrect as the tail (principal piece and end piece) contains the axoneme and outer dense fibers but no mitochondria

 

Educational Objective: 


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece, providing energy for sperm motility.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is undergoing reconstructive surgery after trauma to the chest wall. During the procedure, the surgeon uses a muscle flap to cover a defect as shown in the image. Which flap is most likely being used in this reconstruction? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serratus anterior flap

 

The Serratus anterior flap is a widely used option for chest wall reconstruction, especially in cases involving trauma or oncologic resection. The muscle originates from the lateral surfaces of the upper 8–9 ribs and is inserted into the medial border of the scapula. It is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7) and supplied by the lateral thoracic artery (upper part) and the thoracodorsal artery (lower part). This flap can be rotated medially to cover large defects in the pectoral region, making it the flap of choice for lateral chest wall reconstruction in the described case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectoral myocutaneous flap: This flap is also used in chest wall reconstruction, but it primarily covers anterior chest defects. The described rotation pattern (lateral to medial) is more characteristic of the serratus anterior flap.

 

Option C. TRAM flap: The Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is usually employed in breast reconstruction, not chest wall defects, making it less relevant to this scenario.

 

Option D. VRAM flap: The Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (VRAM) flap is also used for breast or abdominal wall reconstruction and is not typically used for the chest wall, as suggested in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Serratus anterior flap is a versatile muscle flap used for chest wall reconstruction. It is often rotated medially to cover lateral or pectoral defects due to its excellent blood supply and robust arc of rotation.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

 

  • RT-PCR is a molecular biology technique used to amplify and analyze RNA.
  • It involves the conversion of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA.
  • RT-PCR is specifically used for RNA analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Western blotting is a technique used to detect and analyze proteins.
  • It involves the separation of proteins by gel electrophoresis and their subsequent transfer to a membrane for detection using antibodies specific to the protein of interest.
  • Western blotting primarily deals with proteins, not RNA.

 

Option C. Sanger's method (Sanger Sequencing):

  • Sanger sequencing is a DNA sequencing technique developed by Frederick Sanger.
  • It is used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA strands.
  • Sanger sequencing deals with DNA, not RNA.

 

Option D. G-banding:

  • G-banding is a cytogenetic staining technique used to visualize and analyze the banding patterns of chromosomes.
  • It is used in karyotyping and primarily focuses on the visualization of chromosomal DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sangerâ€™s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

 

Ref- Lehninger 6th e/p 331

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains â†’ Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray shown below. Identify the likely cause:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital

 

Explanation:

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Congenital scoliosis is the most frequent congenital deformity of the spine.
  • Congenital curvatures are due to anomalous development of the vertebrae (failure of formation and/or segmentation).
  • In most cases, congenital scolioses are non-hereditary.
  • It is believed to be related to an insult to the fetus during spine embryological development (between the 5th-8th week of gestation).
  • 25% of curves are non-progressive, 25% mildly progressive and 50% highly progressive and will require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is either observation or surgery.
  • The rigidity of the curve is assessed, and the rib hump measured.
  • Associated malformations must be looked for clinically: look for foot or leg asymmetry, craniofacial malformation, a Klippel-Feil web neck, and cardiac and urinary malformations.
  • Full-body-width Postero-anterior (PA) and lateral X-rays are essential.
  • After 1 year of age, X-rays should be taken standing, with the legs in extension and the pelvis level, to compensate for any leg length discrepancy.
  • The Cobb angle will be measured.
  • CT scans shows a bony bar.
  • Congenital scoliosis can be classified into defect of formation or defect of segmentation:
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra (two growth plates) with a contralateral bar
    • Unilateral unsegmented bar
    • Two consecutives fully segmented hemivertebrae
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra
    • Semi segmented hemivertebra
    • Wedge vertebra (partial failure of formation)
    • Incarcerated hemivertebra (smaller and induce little deformity as the hemivertebra sits in a non-growing block; the alignment of the pedicles usually remains straight)

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment consists of either observation of the curve or surgery, or, rarely, bracing.
    • Observation should be applied only for non-progressive curves with a balanced spine.
    • Bracing is inefficient in congenital scoliosis. It may be indicated for long flexible curves or to control the compensatory lumbar curve or help rebalancing the spine, or it may be used after an operation, for instance, until the fusion is solid.
    • Surgery is the mainstay of care.
    • Prophylactic surgery:  surgery that will prevent further worsening or allow progressive correction over time. These operations are in situ fusion and hemi epiphysiodesis.
    • In situ fusion can be done with a single posterior fusion, with or without instrumentation or with an anterior fusion, or a 360Â° fusion.

 

 

  • Hemiepiphysiodesis tends to achieve progressive correction over time, taking advantage of the intact growth plates on the concave side of the deformity.  It has to be done ideally before the age of 5 to take advantage of the growth potential of the spine to allow a progressive correction of the deformity. It should not be carried out if there is a kyphosis component to the deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic. Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial. It is grouped by age. In children age 3 and younger, it is called infantile scoliosis. In age 4-10, it is called juvenile scoliosis. In age >10, it is called adolescent scoliosis. Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending (Adams test) as opposed to postural scoliosis. Compensatory curve due to limb length discrepancy or sciatic list (due to disc prolapsed) disappear on sitting.  Postural scoliosis disappears on forward bending.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular. This type is caused by a nervous system problem such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and polio. It may present at any age; and in many cases progresses relentlessly, particularly in patients with more severe neurologic and systemic involvement. Progressive deformity may limit mobility and seating status, and may be associated with primary or secondary effects on cardiopulmonary function over time. Management includes observation, non-operative interventions such as bracing, specialized seating systems, and surgery.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis. It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue. It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system. Clinical presentation includes-cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd m.c), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachy- dermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows hemivertebra and block vertebra, which are characteristic of congenital type of scoliosis.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

 

The patient presents with a productive cough characterized by tenacious white sputum. In such cases, it is essential to use a treatment that helps break down and clear the mucus to prevent further complications like infections.

 

Syrup Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that works by breaking down mucus, making it easier to clear from the respiratory tract. This is the most appropriate treatment for a patient with thick, tenacious sputum as it will help in liquefying the mucus and promoting its expulsion through coughing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: This combination does not make sense therapeutically. Dextromethorphan is an antitussive, which suppresses cough, while bromhexine is a mucolytic, which helps break down mucus. Using them together is illogical because you do not want to suppress the cough when the patient has productive sputum that needs to be expelled.

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: Codeine is also an antitussive and should not be used in patients with productive cough. Suppressing the cough can lead to accumulation of sputum, which can cause infections.

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Similar to codeine, dextromethorphan is an antitussive and is not appropriate for treating a productive cough. It will suppress the cough reflex, leading to retention of mucus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a productive cough and thick, tenacious sputum, mucolytic agents like bromhexine should be used to help break down and clear the mucus, rather than suppressing the cough reflex with antitussives.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positional asphyxia

 

The position shown is Jack-knife position that leads to positional asphyxia (Restriction of lung expansion d/t abnormal position of the body). It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wedging: Infant falls in the small gap between wall & bed and getting wedged there. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option B) Burking: Accused sits on chest of victim & closes mouth/ nostril as well. Its Mechanism is smothering combined with traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option D) Traumatic asphyxia: it is asphyxia due to restriction of lung expansion as a result of mechanical fixation of chest and not due to abnormal body position hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Mechanical Asphyxia

 

1. Suffocation Asphyxia

  • Smothering
  • Gagging
  • Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia)
  • Positional Asphyxia (Postural Asphyxia)
  • Burking
  • Overlaying
  • Choking (CafÃ© Coronary)

 

2. Compression of neck

  • Hanging â€“ force is body weight / body is suspended
  • Strangulation â€“ force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

 

3. Drowning
